choices.text: Measurement of serum carcinoembryonic antigen (CEA) concentration

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Cholangiocarcinoma, a malignancy of the bile ducts, characteristically presents late in its course with signs of biliary tree obstruction, including abdominal discomfort, weight loss, nausea, jaundice, and pruritus. Patients may report dark urine or light, pale stools. Many persons have no risk factors; however, those with a history of cirrhosis, sclerosing cholangitis, hepatitis B or C, liver fluke infection, and ulcerative colitis may be at increased risk. Diagnosis occurs through imaging of the abdomen with CT scan or MRI, which may disclose a variety of findings from bile duct wall thickening, a focal mass, or only dilation of bile ducts proximal to the presumed lesion location. Endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography (ERCP) allows for the potential direct visualization of the lesion location, bile duct scrapings or biopsy for definitive diagnosis, and stenting of any associated occlusion. Laboratory analysis typically discloses obstructive (direct) hyperbilirubinemia and increased alkaline phosphatase activity. Treatment includes surgical resection and chemotherapy; however, the condition is often late-stage or terminal at the time of diagnosis. lncorrectAnswers:A, C, D, and E. Measurement of serum carcinoembryonic antigen (CEA) concentration (Choice A) is sometimes increased in cholangiocarcinoma; however, it is nonspecific and is also increased in colorectal carcinoma along with other various malignancies. It may be followed during treatment to assess treatment response but does not have a specific role in diagnosis. Hepatobiliary scintigraphy (HIDA scan) (Choice C) evaluates the patency of the hepatobiliary tree and gallbladder. It is useful in cases of suspected acute cholecystitis, choledocholithiasis, or biliary obstruction with indeterminate ultrasonography findings. It does not permit tissue sampling such as biopsy or therapeutic interventions such as stenting. Liver biopsy (Choice D) is useful in the diagnosis of conditions such as cirrhosis, hepatitis, and hepatocellular carcinoma, though cholangiocarcinoma is generally small and confined to the biliary tree. These features may result in false negative liver biopsy results and should prompt targeted sampling via ERCP. Exploratory laparotomy (Choice E) involves the surgical evaluation of the peritoneal cavity and is commonly employed in the diagnosis and management of abdominal trauma, bowel obstruction, peritonitis, and undifferentiated cases of an acute abdomen. It does not have an immediate role in the diagnosis or management of cholangiocarcinoma. r " , r-- r ,

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: The initial evaluation of a critically ill patient includes assessing the airway, breathing, circulation, central nervous system, and any external threats to morbidity or mortality. The initial airway assessment determines whether the patient is at risk for compromise to the pathway of airflow from the external environment into the lungs. Examples of airway compromise include structural lesions (angioedema, facial or neck trauma, airway foreign bodies, expanding neck hematomas), space-filling lesions (pharyngeal, laryngeal, tracheal, or bronchial hemorrhage), uncontrolled emesis, or loss of airway protective reflexes (altered mental status). Airway management requires immediate priority whenever a compromising lesion is detected, and an expanding neck hematoma under arterial pressure (pulsatile) may threaten the pathway of airflow within minutes. Endotracheal intubation is the best

distractor_explanations.A: may be necessary in the evaluation of a penetrating neck trauma; however, it should follow emergent management of the airway, breathing, and circulation, as it is a less immediate threat. Arteriography (
distractor_explanations.C: may be indicated to assess damage to the carotid arteries or their branches; however, in an unstable patient with an expanding, pulsatile neck hematoma, securing the airway and empirically controlling bleeding are earlier priorities. Additionally, zone two neck injuries are generally managed by direct exploration, whereas zone one and zone three injuries are managed first with vessel imaging before operative exploration. Cricothyroidotomy (
distractor_explanations.D: and tracheostomy (
distractor_explanations.E: may be indicated in cases of airway compromise in which endotracheal intubation is unsuccessful. However, in cases of an expanding, arterial neck hematoma, these maneuvers may be difficult or impossible depending on the location of the hematoma. Additionally, inadvertent decompression of an arterial hematoma in the neck may result in exsanguination along with additional airway compromise via hemorrhage into the newly created ostomy. r " , r-- r ,

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Osteoarthritis is a noninflammatory arthropathy that occurs secondary to deterioration of articular cartilage. It typically occurs in older persons and may affect any joint. It is commonly associated with the fingers and wrists because of repetitive use, and the hips and knees because of chronic weight bearing, especially in persons with obesity. It is not associated with infectious or inflammatory symptoms and is generally insidious in onset. Patients typically report chronic pain in a joint that is worse with movement or exertion and is improved with rest, often with limited range of motion in a joint because of underlying joint space narrowing and associated pain. Fever, chills, erythema over a joint, traumatic injury, or extra-articular manifestations (e.g., rashes, uveitis, urethritis) suggest an alternate, inflammatory, or infectious cause. Imaging may demonstrate osteophytosis, subchondral cystic or sclerotic changes, and space narrowing of joints. Arthrocentesis typically demonstrates leukocytes of less than 2,000/mm 3 with no additional abnormalities. Treatment includes rest, physical therapy, nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs, intra-articular injections (e.g., cortisone), and joint replacement surgery for severe or refractory cases.

distractor_explanations.A: presents with pain that radiates down the leg along a specific dermatome secondary to impingement or stretching of a lumbar nerve root, and it often results from underlying degenerative changes of the lumbar spine. It is classically worse with a straight-leg raise maneuver, which stretches the lumbar root and elicits radicular pain, often described as "shooting down the leg." Osteoarthritis of the knee (
distractor_explanations.C: is common in older persons and those with obesity. Pain with osteoarthritis of the knee classically occurs in the knee joint itself and would be unlikely to radiate to the groin or thigh. It may also be associated with knee joint instability. Rheumatoid arthritis of the hip (
distractor_explanations.D: typically is worse in the morning (after a period of rest) with prolonged joint stiffness and improves with use. Extra-articular manifestations of rheumatoid arthritis may also be present such as rheumatoid nodules, pulmonary fibrosis, vasculitis, Sjogren syndrome, and dermatologic manifestations. Trochanteric bursitis (
distractor_explanations.E: presents with localized pain and swelling, often with overlying erythema in the area of the affected bursa. A common risk factor is prolonged pressure applied to the bursa. The associated pain generally does not radiate. r " , r-- r ,

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: BRCA 1, a hereditary tumor suppressor gene, is highly associated with the development of breast and ovarian malignancies when it is nonfunctional, suppressed, or subfunctional. BRCA 1 expression is low in the majority of high-grade, ductal breast and epithelial ovarian cancers. BRCA 1 plays an important role in the repair of double-stranded DNA breaks, and absent or low-expression of this protein promotes mutations which may eventually lead to malignancy. In families with a strong history of early breast and/or ovarian malignancy, with a known BRCA 1 mutation, the risk for breast or ovarian cancer in women can be decreased through a bilateral mastectomy and oophorectomy.

distractor_explanations.B: and tamoxifen therapy and bilateral oophorectomy (
distractor_explanations.D: would limit the patient's risk for either breast cancer or ovarian cancer, respectively, but would still present an increased risk for additional BRCA-associated cancers. Tamoxifen has been shown to reduce the risk for developing breast cancer, but to a lesser extent than prophylactic mastectomy. Tamoxifen therapy and bilateral mastectomy and oophorectomy (
distractor_explanations.C: would not offer additional preventive benefit as compared to isolated surgical removal, as once the organs are no longer present, the risk for malignancy is minimized provided a complete resection occurred. Tamoxifen therapy only (
distractor_explanations.E: may reduce the risk for breast cancer but has been hypothesized to increase the risk for ovarian cancer through the development of ovarian cysts. r " , r-- r ,

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Basal cell carcinoma is the most common skin neoplasm. It typically presents as a slow-growing, pink, waxy skin lesion with telangiectasias, central ulceration, or rolled borders that occurs in sun-exposed areas of the body, especially the face. It can also appear as a nonhealing ulcer. It can be locally invasive but is unlikely to metastasize. Treatment requires excisional biopsy with negative margins, and if locally infiltrative or involving sensitive facial structures, may require Mohs surgery for appropriate resection.

distractor_explanations.A: is a premalignant lesion that may progress to squamous cell carcinoma. They present as chronic rough, scaly patches of skin in areas of prolonged sun exposure (e.g., face, ears, hands). Keratoacanthoma (
distractor_explanations.C: refers to a low-grade tumor that arises from pilosebaceous units and is thought to be related to or a variant of squamous cell carcinoma. They typically regress spontaneously, though they have the ability to invade and metastasize in rare cases. They appear as a papule with a central keratin plug, and generally expand rapidly over weeks. Melanoma (
distractor_explanations.D: is likely to be present when a skin lesion demonstrates asymmetry, irregular-appearing borders, variable coloration, a diameter greater than 6 mm, and rapid evolution in characteristics. Malignant melanoma has the ability to rapidly invade and metastasize, which carries a poor prognosis when diagnosed late. Traumatic ulcer (
distractor_explanations.E: presents as a chronic, nonhealing wound in the setting of an injury. They are more common in persons with diabetes mellitus, peripheral vascular disease, and connective tissue disease. r " , r-- r ,

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Blunt abdominal trauma (BAT) in the setting of hemodynamic stability is best evaluated using a CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis. BAT is commonly associated with injury involving the liver, spleen, and kidneys, and can include hematomas, contusions, lacerations, and in severe cases, devascularization and uncontrolled hemorrhage. Hematuria is highly suggestive of renal or retroperitoneal bleeding or hematoma. In contrast to stable BAT, hemodynamically unstable BAT is evaluated first with focused assessment with sonography for trauma (FAST) followed by an exploratory laparotomy if positive, whereas stable BAT permits time for more thorough evaluation and the additional detail offered in a CT scan. Patients should also receive intravenous fluids, pain control, and supportive care as needed. There should be close monitoring of the patient's hemodynamics, as decompensation may occur rapidly if bleeding is present or continues unabated.

distractor_explanations.A: has a role in the evaluation of renal function following BAT but would not have an immediate role in the evaluation of a traumatic renal injury until such an injury is identified on a CT scan. Cystography (
distractor_explanations.C: and cystoscopy (
distractor_explanations.E: have roles in the workup of hematuria when a bladder source is suspected. Retrograde urethrography (
distractor_explanations.D: permits evaluation of the urethra as a source of hematuria. However, in undifferentiated cases of BAT, a CT scan permits evaluation of the liver, spleen, kidneys, ureters, retroperitoneum, bladder, bony pelvis, and prostate, and should precede dedicated bladder or urethral imaging. Exploratory laparotomy (
distractor_explanations.F: is the correct choice in the management of unstable BAT, as it permits the control of hemorrhage and the repair of identified injuries. In stable cases, imaging precedes surgical intervention. r " , r-- r ,

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Myocardial infarction classically presents with chest pain radiating to the arm or jaw and shortness of breath, often with diaphoresis on examination. Vital signs may show hypertension or hypotension depending on cardiac function. If left heart failure ensues, signs and symptoms of pulmonary edema such as shortness of breath, cough, tachypnea, hypoxia, and crackles may be present. If right heart failure occurs, peripheral edema, hepatic congestion, ascites, jugular venous distention, and hypotension may be present. ST-segment elevations in leads 11, Ill, and a VF suggest an inferior wall myocardial infarction, which classically occurs from occlusion of the right coronary artery. Cardiogenic shock is a potential complication. In cardiogenic shock, there is severe dysfunction of the cardiac myocytes, resulting in markedly decreased contractility. Pulmonary artery catheterization typically demonstrates decreased cardiac output and increased pulmonary capillary wedge pressure because of the underlying systolic cardiac dysfunction. Systemic vascular resistance is commonly increased as a physiologic attempt to maintain mean arterial pressure in the setting of reduced cardiac output and peripheral perfusion.

distractor_explanations.H: reflect typical physiology without an associated insult and would not be expected in a case of cardiogenic shock from myocardial infarction. r " , r-- r ,

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Septic arthritis is most commonly caused by Staphylococcus aureus and presents with pain, inability to bear weight, reduced range of motion, fever, chills, nausea, myalgias, arthralgias, and fatigue. Vital signs may disclose a fever, tachycardia, or hypotension if it is complicated by bacteremia or sepsis. Physical examination typically discloses tenderness to palpation of the affected joint, a limited range of motion, pain with range of motion, joint effusion, and overlying cutaneous erythema. Routes of infection include direct inoculation, spread from an adjacent infection such as osteomyelitis, or hematogenous seeding. Diagnosis is through physical examination plus arthrocentesis, which classically discloses a neutrophilic-predominant exudate with a leukocyte count greater than 50,000/mm 3 Organisms are often seen on Gram stain and are detected by • culture. Treatment includes intravenous antibiotics plus emergent surgical incision and drainage to prevent complications including articular erosion, fibrous ankylosis, loss of the ability to ambulate, and the potential for sepsis and even death if severe.

distractor_explanations.A: is appropriate for cases of musculoskeletal pain or inflammatory arthritis but is generally never appropriate for use in a child outside of mucocutaneous lymph node syndrome (Kawasaki disease) because of the risk for Reye syndrome. It does not have a defined role in the management of septic arthritis. Colchicine therapy (
distractor_explanations.B: is appropriate for inflammatory arthritis and is classically used in the treatment of gout. It inhibits microtubule formation which prevents white blood cell translocation into the joint, limiting inflammation and resultant arthropathy. Prednisone therapy (
distractor_explanations.C: is used primarily for inflammatory arthritis and has a role in the management of rheumatoid arthritis, systemic lupus erythematosus-associated arthritis, and seronegative spondyloarthropathies. Daily needle aspiration of the hip until her symptoms resolve (
distractor_explanations.D: would not appropriately resolve the infection. Emergent surgical incision and drainage followed by antibiotics are required to prevent joint complications and potential sepsis. r " , r-- r ,

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Leydig cell tumors arise from the interstitial cells of the testicle, specifically the Leydig cell, which physiologically produces sex hormones in response to stimulus from luteinizing hormone. Generally, Leydig cells secrete androgens in men; however, they can also secrete estrogens, especially in states of dysregulation (e.g., malignancy). In young boys, such upregulation of androgens presents with precocious puberty, while in women it presents with masculinization (e.g., amenorrhea, hirsutism, temporal balding, acne, deepening of the voice, clitoromegaly). Gynecomastia and a testicular nodule in a postpubertal, otherwise healthy male is suggestive of a functional estrogen secreting Leydig cell tumor. Diagnosis requires testicular ultrasonography, followed by orchiectomy and histologic evaluation.

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Following thoracic or abdominal surgery, breathing often creates discomfort for patients by exacerbating postoperative pain. As a result, patients often splint their breathing, resulting in bradypnea and low tidal volume, which will decrease alveolar minute ventilation leading to the development of hypoxemia and acute respiratory acidosis. Underlying respiratory impairment (e.g., history of smoking, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease) may further exacerbate hypoventilation. Vital signs may disclose bradypnea and low arterial oxygen saturation. Physical examination will demonstrate diminished respiratory effort, often with reduced breath sounds at the lung bases because of atelectasis and inadequate diaphragmatic excursion. Arterial blood gas analysis may disclose an acidic pH with increases in both Pco and HCO along with low arterial oxygen -, 2 3 tension. Hypoxemia will improve with the administration of supplemental oxygen, whereas hypercapnia will persist until the resolution of ventilatory insufficiency. Pain control, incentive spirometry, and respiratory therapy with lung expansion maneuvers are key initial steps in management.

distractor_explanations.B: may be noted in cases of pulmonary embolism, pulmonary hypertension, right-sided heart failure, or the presence of a right-to-left shunt. Increased alveolar-arterial oxygen gradient (
distractor_explanations.C: occurs in cases of right-to-left shunt, ventilation-perfusion mismatch, diffusion abnormality, and dead space; the alveolar-arterial oxygen gradient is normal in cases of isolated alveolar hypoventilation. Increased metabolic demands (
distractor_explanations.D: generally result in increased minute ventilation. The respiratory system compensates for the increased production of carbon dioxide and organic acids through increased ventilation. Increased physiologic dead space (
distractor_explanations.E: may occur in cases where the alveolar membrane no longer functions correctly or is not appropriately perfused (e.g., pulmonary embolism). This results in the presence of air within an alveolus for which gas exchange does not occur. r " , r-- r ,

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Congenital heart disease is often subdivided into cyanotic and noncyanotic types depending on the direction of blood shunting. Structural heart defects that result in flow of deoxygenated blood from the pulmonary to systemic circulations (a right-to-left shunt) classically present with cyanosis, respiratory distress, hypoxia, tachypnea, tachycardia, and hypotension generally within 1 to 7 days after birth. Common culprit lesions include truncus arteriosus, transposition of the great vessels, tricuspid atresia, tetralogy of Fallo!, and total anomalous pulmonary venous return. These lesions require the concomitant presence of a left-to-right shunt (patent ductus arteriosus) to allow for a degree of blood oxygenation. Without a left-to-right shunt, a complete absence of oxygenation can occur because of the separated circulatory systems, which is incompatible with life. In cases of a suspected congenital cyanotic heart defect, intravenous prostaglandin should be started, which maintains a patent ductus arteriosus. Administration of indomethacin or similar nonsteroidal anti inflammatory medications should be avoided, as these will result in closure of the ductus arteriosus. Echocardiography is required to determine the structural defects to confirm the right-to-left shunt and to assist in operative planning.

distractor_explanations.B: can provide structural but only limited functional information about the heart, whereas an echocardiography permits analysis of structural defects, pressure, velocity, and flow of blood which is important in understanding the hemodynamics associated with structural heart disease. Administration of indomethacin (
distractor_explanations.C: would result in closure of the ductus arteriosus and could worsen the degree of right-to-left shunting with resultant severe hypoxia. Administration of surfactant (
distractor_explanations.D: may have an adjunct role in certain cases of neonatal respiratory distress syndrome because of the inadequate production of surfactant in the setting of premature birth; however, the pulmonary function in congenital heart disease is often not affected. Cardiac catheterization (
distractor_explanations.E: may be necessary to further assist in evaluation of the heart anatomy and intracardiac pressures, but it is not the best

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Acute cholecystitis occurs secondary to obstruction of the cystic duct from a lodged gallstone, which results in subsequent inflammation of the gallbladder wall. It classically presents with fever, abdominal pain, and tenderness to palpation in the right upper quadrant, often in a patient with a history of gallstones. It is occasionally preceded by symptoms of biliary colic. It is more commonly seen in women with obesity in their 40s to 50s, especially those having a history of multi parity. Risk factors include gallstones, biliary sludge, or conditions that slow or delay gastric emptying or reduce contractility of the gallbladder such as pregnancy or total parenteral nutrition. Diagnosis is through clinical history, physical examination, and ultrasonography, which may disclose pericholecystic fluid, a dilated gallbladder, gallbladder wall thickening and hyperemia, the presence of gallstones, and a sonographic Murphy sign (pain with compression directly over the gallbladder). Treatment involves surgical resection of the gallbladder (cholecystectomy). lncorrectAnswers:A, B, D, E, and F. Abruptio placentae (Choice A) presents with vaginal bleeding, severe uterine pain, and tetanic contractions, typically in the third trimester. It commonly results from lower abdominal trauma, smoking, or cocaine use. Acute appendicitis (Choice B) presents with periumbilical pain that migrates to the right lower quadrant, fever, anorexia, nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, and leukocytosis. r " , r-- r ,

20. A 77-year-old man is brought to the emergency department after being rescued from a house fire . Firefighters found him unconscious in his bed; the bedroom was full of smoke . The firefighters and paramedics state that the
patient probably fell asleep while smoking in bed. On arrival , he does not respond to verbal stimuli and has cough productive of carbonaceous sputum . His temperature is 37.8°C (100°F) , pulse is 120/min , respirations are 30/min
and labored , and blood pressure is 98/78 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on 50% oxygen by face mask shows an oxygen saturation of 93% . Examination shows second degree burns over the face and upper extremities . There is
marked facial edema , and the eyebrows are singed . On pulmonary examination , air movement is poor. Stridor and wheezes are heard over the lung bases bilaterally . The patient's carboxyhemoglobin concentration is 35% .
Arterial blood gas analysis on 50% oxygen by face mask shows :
pH 7.25
Pco 65 mm Hg
2
Po 45 mm Hg
2
After endotracheal intubation and administration of 100% oxygen, this patient should receive fluid resuscitation with which of the following during the next 12 hours?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Ovarian cancer classically presents late in the course and is often metastatic and invasive at the time of discovery. Presenting features are often nonspecific and may include weight loss, abdominal discomfort or distention, ascites, and gastrointestinal symptoms including early satiety, bloating, nausea, cramping, and bowel obstruction. Bowel obstruction can occur because of locally invasive disease or because of peritoneal carcinomatosis, which is often a common presenting diagnosis. Spread of the malignancy throughout the peritoneum results in bowel and omental implants, which on gross surgical examination is described as "caking." The resultant mechanical distortion, tethering, and compression of bowel leads to obstruction in a similar mechanism to postoperative adhesions and strictures. Any incidental ovarian enlargement or cyst in a woman over age 50 years should be investigated for malignancy with imaging and potentially biopsy. Ovarian cancer is also potentially hereditary, with an increased frequency of cases seen in women with mutations in BRCA 1/2 and hereditary nonpolyposis colorectal cancer. Treatment includes surgical resection and debulking plus chemotherapy. Early diagnosis and treatment are key to maximize survival.

distractor_explanations.A: is incorrect as colloids are generally not deficient in the setting of burns (e.g., albumin). The administration of isotonic crystalloids alone is the standard of care for resuscitative fluid administration as it provides the most direct intravascular benefit. Fresh frozen plasma (
distractor_explanations.B: is appropriate for use as a resuscitation fluid in cases of severe blood loss as part of a balanced resuscitation treatment plan. It is also used in reversing anticoagulation when prothrombin complex concentrates are not available. It does not have a primary role in the fluid resuscitation of patients with burns. Hypertonic crystalloid solution only (
distractor_explanations.C: is used in the management of acute hyponatremia with neurologic deficits and to reduce cerebral edema in cases of elevated intracranial pressure. It does not have a primary role in the fluid resuscitation of patients with burns. Packed red blood cells (
distractor_explanations.E: are used as a component of resuscitation in cases of hemorrhagic shock. Unless blood loss or severe anemia is also present, they are not used in the fluid resuscitation of patients with burns. r " , r-- r ,

vignette.presentation:
22. An 8-year-old girl has had migrating polyarthralgia and fever for 4 days . She appears ill. Examination shows an evanescent rash . Her left knee is red, swollen , and tender . The chest is clear to auscultation . A grade 4/6 ,
holosystolic apical murmur is heard with radiation to the axilla . There is no organomegaly . Which of the following is the most likely cardiac abnormality?

question_stem: the most likely cardiac abnormality?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Acute rheumatic fever (ARF) may present with migratory polyarthralgia, pancarditis (pericarditis, myocarditis, or endocarditis), subcutaneous nodules, erythema marginatum, Sydenham chorea, fever, increased erythrocyte sedimentation rate, and short PR interval following an infection from group A streptococci, most often pharyngitis. The mitral valve is the most commonly affected. Antibodies to M protein enhance host defenses against group A streptococci but can result in an autoimmune attack against self-antigens through molecular mimicry. This can result in valve inflammation and acute regurgitation. Chronic mitral regurgitation, prolapse, or stenosis can result as potential long-term sequelae.

distractor_explanations.A: presents with a crescendo-decrescendo systolic murmur that is heard best at the upper right sternal border and radiates to the carotid arteries. It classically occurs secondary to age-related fibrotic and calcific changes of the valve but can occur earlier in life in cases of bicuspid aortic valve or chronic rheumatic disease. Tetralogy of Fallo! (
distractor_explanations.C: consists of pulmonary infundibular stenosis, overriding aorta, ventricular septal defect, and right ventricular hypertrophy, resulting in a right-to-left shunt with cyanosis first noted in infancy. The murmur heard with Tetralogy of Fallo! relates to the underlying ventricular septal defect, characterized by a holosystolic murmur heard best in the lower left sternal border, and to the pulmonic stenosis, characterized by a systolic crescendo-decrescendo murmur in the pulmonic listening area. Tricuspid regurgitation (
distractor_explanations.E: is characterized by a holosystolic murmur heard best in the lower left sternal border. VSD generally presents at birth and is not associated with ARF. r " , r-- r ,

vignette.presentation:
23. A 24-year-old man comes to the emergency department 60 minutes after the sudden onset of tearing chest pain radiating to his back. He has no history of serious illness and takes no medications . He does not smoke . He is
190 cm (6 ft 3 in) tall and weighs 80 kg (176 lb); BMI is 22 kg/m 2 His temperature is 37.2°C (99°F), pulse is 120/min, respirations are 14/min, and blood pressure is 110/70 mm Hg in his right arm and 70/40 mm Hg in his left arm.
•
Pulse oximetry on 2 L/min of oxygen via nasal cannula shows an oxygen saturation of 100%. Cardiopulmonary examination shows no abnormalities . The lungs are clear to auscultation . Heart sounds are normal. Pulses are
difficult to palpate in the left upper extremity. Peripheral pulses are otherwise normal. A chest x-ray shows a widened upper mediastinum . An ECG shows sinus tachycardia with no acute changes . Which of the following is the
most appropriate next step in management?

question_stem: most appropriate next step in management?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Labetalol is a first-line antihypertensive medication used to decrease blood pressure in the setting of presumed aortic dissection, which classically presents with severe, acute, tearing chest pain radiating to the back, differential blood pressures between extremities, and a widened mediastinum on a chest x-ray. To prevent further progression of the dissection flap, controlling the patient's heart rate and blood pressure is the first priority. An intravenous ~-adrenergic blocking agent should be used with a goal of decreasing the heart rate to approximately 60/min and the blood pressure to less than 100 to 120 mm Hg systolic and 60 to 80 mm Hg diastolic. Decreasing the heart rate helps prevent the advancement of the dissection flap and resultant occlusion of branch vessels by limiting the pulse pressure differential. Labetalol is a nonspecific adrenoreceptor blocker that targets both ar and ~radrenoreceptors, making it an ideal choice for the management of the patient's heart rate, cardiac contractility, and vascular resistance.

distractor_explanations.A: would be appropriate in the management of an acute coronary syndrome. Administering therapeutic anticoagulation in the setting of an aortic dissection increases the risk for severe thoracic hemorrhage and exsanguination if there is an associated aneurysm and/or damage to the tunica adventitia. Administration of nitroglycerin (
distractor_explanations.C: may be appropriate in cases of aortic dissection for blood pressure control if the goal is not met with adrenoreceptor blockade; however, it would follow administration of a ~ adrenergic blocking agent to prevent reflex tachycardia and widening of pulse pressure. Fiberoptic intubation (
distractor_explanations.D: may be appropriate for a patient with a compromised airway, but in cases without an impending threat to the airway would be superseded by management of the immediate life threatening condition, the patient's aortic dissection. Pericardiocentesis (
distractor_explanations.E: is appropriate in cases of pericardia! effusion and/or tamponade, which would present following symptoms of pericarditis, or with muffled heart sounds, jugular venous distention, and hypotension iftamponade from any cause is present. Pulsus paradoxus may be seen on examination. r " , r-- r ,

vignette.presentation:
24. A 62-year-old woman comes to the physician because of ulcers on her right ankle for 6 months . There is no history of recent trauma . She has a 5-year history of type 2 diabetes mellitus treated with insulin for the past 4 years
and a 2-year history of chronic bilateral ankle swelling . Her temperature is 37.?°C (99.9°F) , pulse is 82/min , and blood pressure is 140/88 mm Hg. Examination shows ulceration of the medial aspect of the right ankle . There is
bilateral lower leg and pedal edema with patches of brown pigmentation . Peripheral pulses are present and normal. Which of the following is the most likely pathogenesis of this condition?

question_stem: the most likely pathogenesis of this condition?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Venous insufficiency presents with dependent, pitting edema that improves with compression and elevation, along with paresthesia and hyperpigmentation of the skin (e.g., stasis dermatitis). In severe cases, chronic circulatory insufficiency can result in skin breakdown, leading to the development of open ulcers, classically along the medial aspect of the ankle. Venous insufficiency often results from deep venous thrombosis with resultant damage to the valves. When the thrombus resolves, the residual vessel may be dysfunctional from damage to the valve leaflets, valve annulus, or increased diameter of the native vessel. This prevents the vessel from functioning effectively and results in stagnant or retrograde venous flow secondary to gravity. Treatment includes wound care for the ulcer and measures to reverse the venous insufficiency such as optimizing venous return, diuresis, and improving circulatory function by optimizing cardiac, vascular, and kidney function.

distractor_explanations.A: classically presents with claudication; thin, waxy, hairless skin; an absence of edema; and painful ulcers classically along the outer ankle, foot, or distal toes. Congestive heart failure {
distractor_explanations.B: presents with shortness of breath, orthopnea, paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea, peripheral edema, jugular venous distention, crackles on examination, and an S or S gallop. It may 3 4 be an indirect cause of venous congestion through stasis and hypervolemia. Neurotrophic ulcer {
distractor_explanations.C: results from repetitive trauma or compression in areas of impaired sensation. Such ulcers are commonly seen overlying bony prominences (e.g., metatarsal heads) in cases of peripheral neuropathy from diabetes mellitus. Thromboangiitis obliterans {
distractor_explanations.D: is also known as Buerger disease and is a small vessel vasculitis associated with smoking. It typically presents with claudication symptoms that may progress to ulceration, gangrene, and autoamputation of digits. Ulcerations tend to occur in the tips of the fingers and toes. r " , r-- r ,

Examination shows no abnormalities except for a patent arteriovenous fistula in the left forearm . His serum calcium concentration is 8.3 mg/dl , serum phosphorus concentration is 4.1 mg/dl , and serum intact parathyroid
hormone concentration is 485 pg/ml (N=10-65) . Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

question_stem: the most likely diagnosis?

distractor_explanations.A: arises from an abnormal calcium-sensing receptor on parathyroid cells. As a result, PTH is not suppressed by normal or increased serum calcium. This leads to mild hypercalcemia with increased PTH because of the normal mechanism of action of PTH on osteoclasts and renal tubules. Cinacalcet is used to treat the condition, which increases the sensitivity of the calcium-sensing receptor to the presence of serum calcium. Paraneoplastic syndrome {
distractor_explanations.B: defines a pathologic state that arises secondary to the presence of a malignancy; for example, squamous cell carcinoma of the lung may exogenously produce PTH-related peptide (PTH-rP) which functions in the same manner as PTH. Endogenous PTH is downregulated in the setting of exogenous PTH-rP. Primary hyperparathyroidism {
distractor_explanations.C: presents with hypercalcemia, hypophosphatemia, and increased PTH. It occurs because of a parathyroid adenoma, hyperplasia, or carcinoma. Tertiary hyperparathyroidism {
distractor_explanations.E: describes a state of chronic, refractory, autonomous production of PTH in the setting of long-standing kidney disease and presents with hypercalcemia, normal or increased serum phosphate, and increased PTH. r " , r-- r ,

vignette.presentation:
26. A previously healthy 47-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 3-month history of mild hearing loss and ringing in her right ear and a decreased sense of taste on the right. She also has had episodes of
unsteadiness during this period and has had trouble understanding speech . She has not had nausea , vomiting , or vertigo . Examination shows no abnormalities . Audiometry shows predominantly high-frequency neural hearing
loss on the right. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

question_stem: the most likely diagnosis?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Acoustic neuroma (vestibular schwannoma) commonly presents with symptoms of hearing loss, vertigo, and ataxia, often slow in onset and progressive over a subacute to chronic period. Classically, these tumors occur at the cerebellopontine angle of the brain stem and are associated with neurofibromatosis. They may exert mass effect on cranial nerves within their proximity or invade the nerves from which they arise, often the facial nerve, vestibulocochlear nerve, or adjacent nerves. Facial nerve involvement manifests as facial asymmetry because of loss of skeletal muscle innervation and occasionally presents with diminished taste perception involving the ipsilateral anterior two-thirds of the tongue. Vestibulocochlear nerve palsy can present with diminished hearing or tinnitus (cochlear branch) on the ipsilateral side, and vertigo or ataxia may occur (vestibular branch) because of impaired proprioception from loss of input from the ipsilateral vestibule. In cases of larger masses, disruption of brain stem tracts and increased intracranial pressure can result.

distractor_explanations.B: presents with a classic triad of hearing loss, tinnitus, and vertigo, and is caused by fluid overload within the vestibulocochlear apparatus. It would not cause a decreased sense of taste. Meningitis (
distractor_explanations.C: typically presents with headache, fever, photophobia, phonophobia, and neck stiffness, as well as possible Kernig or Brudzinski signs noted on examination. It may be caused by bacterial, viral, fungal, or parasitic infections. Cranial nerve deficits may result, but a chronic presentation involving cranial nerves only would be rare. Otosclerosis (
distractor_explanations.D: results in dysfunction of the ossicles and causes conductive hearing loss; neurologic symptoms of ataxia would be unlikely. Pituitary adenoma (
distractor_explanations.E: can present with mass-like symptoms such as a headache or bitemporal hemianopsia, or with symptoms caused by the functional production of a hormone from the tumor (e.g., galactorrhea secondary to a prolactinoma). Because of the position of the pituitary gland within the sella turcica, symptoms involving the facial nerve or vestibulocochlear nerve would be unlikely. r " , r-- r ,

vignette.presentation:
27. A previously healthy 15-year-old girl is brought to the emergency department 1 hour after the sudden onset of difficulty breathing and sharp chest pain that began during track practice . She is 183 cm (6 ft) tall and weighs
55 kg (121 lb); BMI is 16 kg/m 2 On arrival , her temperature is 37°C (98.6°F) , pulse is 70/min , and respirations are 28/min . Breath sounds are decreased over the lateral chest on the right ; there is hyperresonance to percussion .
.
Cardiac examination shows no abnormalities . Which of the following is the most likely mechanism of these findings?

question_stem: the most likely mechanism of these findings?

choices.text: Air collection in the pleural space

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Pneumothorax results from air entering the intrapleural space from either an external (e.g., stab wound) or internal (e.g., ruptured bleb or bronchus, bronchopleural fistula) source. As the air accumulates within the space, the lung parenchyma becomes compressed, resulting in respiratory distress, reduced breath sounds, hyperresonance to percussion, and in severe cases, tension on the mediastinal structures impeding venous return resulting in hypotension. A spontaneous primary pneumothorax can occur in a tall, thin, young person because of the rupture of a pulmonary bleb, classically in a young athlete and often during physical exertion. Small pneumothoraces can be managed with serial examinations and repeat chest x-rays to confirm resolution. When the lesion is larger than 20 to 30% of the hemithoracic volume, a chest tube should be placed to evacuate the pneumothorax and reinflate the lung to prevent the development of a persistent or permanent pneumothorax. Tension pneumothorax should be immediately decompressed with emergent needle thoracostomy to prevent hemodynamic collapse.

distractor_explanations.B: may present with shortness of breath or be asymptomatic depending on the size and extent. A small, subsegmental atelectatic region may be completely asymptomatic, whereas if an entire lung is involved, the patient may present with shortness of breath, severe hypoxia, diminished ipsilateral breath sounds, and dullness to percussion. Narrowing of moderate-sized airways (
distractor_explanations.C: presents with poor air movement, wheezing or rhonchi, and cough, and describes the pathophysiology of bronchitis. Asthma classically results in narrowing of the small airways. Pleural inflammation (
distractor_explanations.D: presents with pleuritic chest pain, often following a viral respiratory infection. Occasionally, a friction rub may be heard on auscultation, but often the examination and vital signs are unremarkable. Pulmonary parenchymal inflammation (
distractor_explanations.E: describes pneumonitis or pneumonia, which typically presents with chest pain, shortness of breath, and cough; hyperresonance to percussion would not be expected. r " , r-- r ,

(98.6°F) , pulse is 90/min , respirations are 18/min , and blood pressure is 120/75 mm Hg. Examination shows no breast masses . A serosanguineous discharge is easily expressed from the left nipple . Mammography shows no
areas of microcalcification . Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

question_stem: the most likely diagnosis?

distractor_explanations.A: is a potential complication of mastitis, most commonly occurring in breast-feeding women. It typically presents following mastitis, with a localized region of indurated, fluctuant tissue. Breast cancer (
distractor_explanations.B: encompasses many types of breast carcinoma, including invasive ductal and lobular carcinoma, medullary carcinoma, inflammatory breast carcinoma, and cystosarcoma phyllodes. The most common type is invasive ductal carcinoma, which typically presents as a palpable, immobile breast mass, which may demonstrate features such as spiculated margins and microcalcifications on mammography. Malignancies can be associated with pathologic nipple discharge, although intraductal papilloma is the most common cause of unilateral bloody nipple discharge. Ductal ectasia (
distractor_explanations.C: more often occurs in perimenopausal women and is a widening of the lactiferous ducts with thickening of their walls, often near the nipple. Ectatic ducts are often asymptomatic until they become blocked, at which time they may become nodular or painful. Bloody discharge is uncommon. Fat necrosis (
distractor_explanations.D: is often detected in the breast as a palpable nodularity in an area of

vignette.presentation:
29. A 77-year-old woman is admitted to the hospital because of severe cramping pain in the lower abdomen . The pain has been constant for the past 16 hours. The abdomen is
markedly distended . A McBurney incisional scar is noted in the right lower quadrant. The x-ray shown was taken shortly after admission . Which of the following is the most
likely diagnosis?

choices.text: Mechanical obstruction of the small intestine

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: A sigmoid volvulus results from twisting of the sigmoid mesentery, which can lead to large bowel obstruction and perforation or intestinal necrosis if not treated. Patients commonly present with symptoms secondary to a large bowel obstruction such as constipation, abdominal bloating, distention, nausea, and vomiting. Sigmoid volvulus typically demonstrates a coffee-bean appearance on abdominal x-rays with severe distention of the sigmoid colon. In patients without complications such as bowel ischemia or perforation, treatment requires detorsion of the sigmoid colon and mesentery through sigmoidoscopy with placement of a rectal tube to facilitate stool passage and maintain decompression. Recurrent sigmoid volvulus may require surgical colopexy or sigmoid colectomy.

distractor_explanations.A: is often asymptomatic until late in the course. It is classically associated with occult gastrointestinal bleeding and iron deficiency anemia. lleoileal intussusception (
distractor_explanations.B: describes telescoping of one segment of ileum into an adjacent segment, which can cause intestinal ischemia or obstruction. It typically occurs because of a pathologic lead point (e.g., malignancy, stricture, lymphadenopathy), and presents with colicky pain and bloating. Abdominal x-rays are often nondiagnostic for the condition, which is better detailed on ultrasonography (children) or CT scan (adults), which will disclose the intussusceptum. Mechanical obstruction of the small intestine (
distractor_explanations.C: is typically acute, occurring because of adhesions, inflammatory bowel disease, strictures, malignancies, or hernias. It typically presents with abdominal pain, nausea, nonbloody and sometimes bilious emesis, hyperactive and high-pitched bowel sounds, and abdominal distention. X-rays may show dilated loops of small bowel with air-fluid levels. Paralytic ileus (
distractor_explanations.D: refers to intestinal hypomotility without a mechanical obstruction, most commonly occurring following surgery or in the setting of electrolyte abnormalities (e.g., end-stage kidney disease resulting in hyperkalemia). It typically presents with diffuse small and large bowel dilatation. r " , r-- r ,

vignette.presentation:
30. A 32-year-old woman comes to the emergency department 24 hours after the onset of severe abdominal cramps and nausea . During this period , she has vomited yellow-green material once and has had only two bowel
movements , which were small and liquid . During the past 6 months , she has had less severe abdominal cramps associated with diarrhea and a 6.8-kg (15-lb) weight loss . She says the cramps have become more severe during
the past month . She has no history of serious illness and takes no medications . On arrival , she is in moderate distress . She appears pale. She is 165 cm (5 ft 5 in) tall and weighs 52 kg (114 lb); BMI is 19 kg/m 2 Her temperature
.
is 37 .2°C (99°F) , pulse is 90/min , and blood pressure is 116/78 mm Hg. Abdominal examination shows moderate distention with mild right lower quadrant tenderness . Her leukocyte count is 14,000/mm 3 A CT scan of the
•
abdomen shows thickening of the terminal ileum and air in the rectum . The colon is not dilated. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in diagnosis?

question_stem: the most appropriate next step in diagnosis?

choices.text: Upper gastrointestinal series with a water-soluble contrast and small bowel follow-through

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Crohn disease is characterized by transmural inflammation of the gastrointestinal tract, most frequently involving the terminal ileum. It can arise anywhere in the gastrointestinal tract and is a subclass of inflammatory bowel disease. Most patients experience chronic abdominal cramping, bloody diarrhea, anemia, and weight loss. Examination often demonstrates generalized abdominal tenderness, sometimes worse in the right lower quadrant, and, depending on the severity and extent, may disclose complications such as enterocutaneous fistulas and extraintestinal manifestations such as uveitis. Severe Crohn disease can result in intestinal obstruction from stricture or inflammation, bowel perforation, intra-abdominal abscess, and the formation of additional fistulas. Diagnosis occurs through colonoscopy with biopsy, which is the best

distractor_explanations.A: is used to evaluate the lumen of the large bowel to assist in the diagnosis of colonic neoplasms, strictures, fistulas, or postsurgical complications. It does not reliably image the distal small bowel and does not permit sampling of tissue for biopsy. Upper gastrointestinal series with a water-soluble contrast and small bowel follow-through (
distractor_explanations.B: studies are indicated when structural lesions involving the stomach or small bowel are suspected. This is most commonly indicated for the evaluation of small bowel pathology, such as duodenal atresia, malrotation with volvulus, and Crohn disease; however, it would not offer the opportunity to sample tissue through biopsy. MRI of the abdomen (
distractor_explanations.C: offers high-contrast resolution detail of soft-tissue structures within the abdomen. It can be used for the evaluation of a variety of intra-abdominal pathologies. MRI enterography techniques can be utilized to investigate sites of active or chronic bowel inflammation, although this would not permit tissue sampling. Capsule endoscopy (
distractor_explanations.D: is used in the diagnosis of jejunal and proximal ileal pathology located outside of the reachable field of view of upper endoscopy or colonoscopy. It is most commonly used in the workup of small bowel sources of gastrointestinal bleeding or neoplasia. It offers images only and cannot be used for tissue sampling. r " , r-- r ,

vignette.presentation:
32. A previously healthy 32-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department 30 minutes after a motor vehicle collision . She was an unrestrained front seat passenger . On arrival , she has pain and tingling in her right leg and
is unable to move it. Her pulse is 105/min , respirations are 18/min , and blood pressure is 155/90 mm Hg. The right lower extremity is pale . The dorsalis pedis and posterior tibial pulses are absent on the right. There is a posterior
dislocation of the right knee . Motor and sensory function is absent below the right knee . Following reduction of the dislocation and splinting of the right lower extremity , the patient is able to move the leg. Which of the following is
the most appropriate next step in diagnosis?

question_stem: the most appropriate next step in diagnosis?

choices.text: Venous duplex ultrasonography of the right lower extremity
CT scan of the right lower extremity

distractor_explanations.A: is appropriate to investigate the diagnosis of deep venous thrombosis, which can result from stasis in the setting of orthopaedic injury. However, it is not the most likely immediate complication of a knee dislocation. CT scan of the right lower extremity (
distractor_explanations.B: provides detail about bony, vascular, and soft tissue structures; however, a CT angiography protocol would be required for appropriate vessel imaging detail. Arthroscopy (
distractor_explanations.C: may eventually be required in the diagnosis or repair of potentially damaged knee ligaments from the dislocation; however, this is not the most immediate limb-threatening complication. Nerve conduction studies (
distractor_explanations.E: may eventually be indicated to diagnose injury to the distal sciatic nerve branches such as the tibial and peroneal nerves but would not take precedence over arterial injury assessment in a patient where motor function had been restored. No further diagnostic studies necessary (
distractor_explanations.F: is inappropriate; posterior knee dislocation is highly associated with arterial injury and additional studies are indicated to prevent a delay in diagnosis and treatment. r " , r-- r ,

vignette.presentation:
33. A 70-year-old man has a 2-year history of progressive dysphagia and intermittent regurgitation of undigested food . A barium swallow is shown . Which of the following is the most
likely cause?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: A pharyngoesophageal (Zenker) diverticulum occurs within the hypopharynx, just above or at the level of the cricopharyngeus muscle. The mechanism of formation includes an uncoordinated swallowing mechanism, which results in muscle spasms of the cricopharyngeus leading to pulsion diverticula as the wall of the hypopharynx and superior esophagus weakens. Symptoms include halitosis, regurgitation of undigested food, and dysphagia. Barium swallow discloses a posterior, midline outpouching above or at the level of the cricopharyngeus. Treatment includes surgical repair and resection (diverticulectomy), plus dietary modifications to include soft or liquid foods.

distractor_explanations.A: occurs in the setting of autonomic neuropathy, cerebrovascular accident, and achalasia. It generally results in the failure of a food bolus to transit through the hypopharynx and/or esophagus, not in the focal formation of a hypopharyngeal diverticulum. Diffuse esophageal spasm (

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Incidental discoveries during unrelated surgery, when not immediately life-threatening, are appropriately managed by closing the operative site and discussing the findings with the patient when they regain decision making capacity following anesthesia. While discovery of malignancy in a young woman may immediately prompt the thought that treatment would be desired, the decision to pursue intervention is ultimately the patient's choice, upholding the ethical principle of autonomy.

vignette.presentation:
35. An 82-year-old woman is brought to the physician for a follow-up examination 2 months after she sustained a right hip fracture when she fell in her kitchen . Two years ago , she sustained a Colles fracture in a fall. Examination
today shows a well-healed scar over the right hip. Range of motion of the hip joint is full. Her serum calcium concentration is within the reference ranges ; her serum 25-hydroxyvitamin D concentration is decreased . A DEXA scan
shows osteoporosis . Which of the following is the most likely additional serum abnormality in this patient ?

question_stem: the most likely additional serum abnormality in this patient ?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Osteoporosis occurs because of the loss of bone mineral density. The condition results from the interplay of three possible mechanisms: failure to achieve peak bone density, increased bone resorption, and decreased new bone formation. The condition is often asymptomatic until a traumatic injury results in a fracture, most commonly involving the hip, distal radius, or vertebrae. Classically, serum calcium, vitamin D, and magnesium concentrations are within the reference ranges; however, calcium handling in the bloodstream is key in the pathogenesis of osteoporosis. Hypocalcemia and hypovitaminosis D both lead to increased concentrations of parathyroid hormone (PTH), which results in increased osteoclast activity and bone resorption. Low concentrations of vitamin D are also associated with increased concentrations of PTH even when serum calcium is within the reference range. The diagnosis of osteoporosis is made based on DEXA scan once the bone density falls below 2.5 standard deviations of the mean for a young adult. Treatment includes correcting any modifiable risk factors, supplementing calcium and vitamin D, weight-bearing exercise therapy, and the use of osteoclast inhibitors (e.g., bisphosphonates).

distractor_explanations.A: results in a low active vitamin D concentration in the setting of end-stage kidney disease because of loss of parenchymal cells that synthesize the enzyme and the resultant inability to convert 25-hydroxyvitamin D to 1,25-dihydroxyvitamin D, the active form. A deficiency of this enzyme would be uncommon outside of a primary kidney disease. Nutritional deficiency of vitamin D is more likely when the precursor 25-hydroxyvitamin D concentration is low. Decreased thyroxine (T concentration (
distractor_explanations.B: presents with symptoms of hypothyroidism including weight gain, lethargy, fatigue, constipation, hair loss, and cold intolerance. Thyroid hormone promotes bone ) 4 mineral density; however, in the absence of additional symptoms of hypothyroidism, a deficiency of thyroxine is less likely. Increased calcitonin concentration (
distractor_explanations.C: classically presents with hypocalcemia, as calcitonin promotes osteoblast activity with resultant bone mineral deposition. Increased osteocalcin concentration (
distractor_explanations.D: is a marker of bone formation and is correlated with increases in bone mineral density, for example, when bone-forming medications such as teriparatide are used. r " , r-- r ,

vignette.presentation:
36. A 25-year-old man comes for a routine health maintenance examination. A harsh systolic murmur is heard. Examination shows no other abnormalities . Echocardiography shows a bicuspid aortic valve . This patient is at increased
risk for aortic stenosis as a result of which of the following?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Calcification of the valve is a pathologic consequence of mechanical stresses on heart valves and results from repetitive microtrauma from the opening and closing of valve leaflets with associated chronic inflammation. Many people will develop some degree of valve stenosis because of chronic inflammation with resultant calcification and fibrosis over time, with the aortic valve most commonly affected. Structural abnormalities of the valve, such as a bicuspid aortic valve, alter the biomechanics of valve opening and closing, which increases the likelihood of earlier calcification and resultant stenosis because of increased mechanical trauma. Congenital bicuspid aortic valve classically presents with early signs and symptoms of aortic stenosis and left-sided diastolic heart failure. Patients may report fatigue, shortness of breath, cough, diminished exercise tolerance, or syncope with exertion. Examination findings include a crescendo-decrescendo systolic murmur heard best at the upper right sternal border, and pulsus parvus et tardus (weak and delayed) may be noted on examination of peripheral pulses. Because of the chronic increased afterload from a fixed obstruction by the valve, left ventricular hypertrophy and resultant diastolic dysfunction can occur. If early aortic stenosis occurs, the patient may be a candidate for aortic valve replacement.

distractor_explanations.B: describes the principal risk factor for coronary artery disease, cerebrovascular accidents, and peripheral artery disease. The presence of a plaque within the arterial wall acts as a nidus for thrombus formation when the plaque ruptures. This does not play a role in the development of aortic stenosis. Rupture of the chordae tendineae (
distractor_explanations.C: may occur following a myocardial infarction. It typically leads to acute valvular regurgitation and is classically associated with acute pulmonary edema from mitral regurgitation. Streptococcal infection (
distractor_explanations.D: is associated with rheumatic heart disease, which results in inflammation of the valves of the heart, most commonly the mitral and aortic valves. This may present with acute regurgitant murmurs and chronically can result in stenosis. This patient's bicuspid aortic valve is his main risk factor for early-onset aortic stenosis. Thrombus deposition on the valve (
distractor_explanations.E: is commonly seen in cases of mechanical valve replacement with subtherapeutic anticoagulation. The nonendothelialized valve surface acts as a nidus for thrombus formation. r " , r-- r ,

38. A 55-year-old man comes to the physician's office because of claudication . He smokes two packs of cigarettes per day and has no history of diabetes mellitus . The femoral pulses are palpable bilaterally , and distal pulses are
absent. Capillary refill in both feet is less than 5 seconds . Ankle-arm indices are 0.75 on the right and 0.60 on the left. In addition to recommending that he quit smoking , which of the following is the most appropriate initial step in
patient care?

question_stem:
the most appropriate initial step in
patient care?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Prescription for an exercise program is the most appropriate initial step in management for this patient. Leg pain that occurs following exertion and improves with rest is known as claudication and indicates the presence of peripheral vascular disease. Claudication results from increased physiologic demand of the skeletal musculature for oxygen, which cannot be met because of the fixed obstruction to flow of stenotic arteries. As demand falls during rest, the pain typically improves. Peripheral vascular disease is common among older men who smoke cigarettes and have a history of hypertension, diabetes mellitus, or hyperlipidemia. Active exercise improves collateral vascularization, which allows for improved arterial oxygenated blood flow to the skeletal musculature and is the best initial step in treatment along with the mitigation of risk factors. Additional therapeutic options include cilostazol and surgical revascularization (e.g., bypass, stenting), which can be employed following exercise therapy.

distractor_explanations.A: and femoropopliteal bypass (
distractor_explanations.B: are both invasive options that should be reserved for when noninvasive therapy is no longer sufficient. Sympathectomy (
distractor_explanations.C: refers to the removal of a sympathetic nerve root and is often used in hyperhidrosis, reflex sympathetic dystrophy, and Raynaud disease. The disease cause of claudication is generally not because of sympathetically mediated vasoconstriction, and sympathectomy does not generally play a role in treatment. Vasodilator therapy (
distractor_explanations.D: (e.g., cilostazol) may have a role in treating this patient's claudication, but it will not promote collateral vascularization which improves long-term symptoms. Because of this, initial treatment with a regimented exercise program is recommended. r " , r-- r ,

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Spontaneous bacterial peritonitis (SBP) occurs most frequently in cirrhotic states, although it can occur in any setting causing ascites. SBP describes an infection within ascitic fluid in the peritoneal cavity, most often from translocated enteric flora such as Escherichia coli. The classic presentation includes fever along with diffuse abdominal pain and tenderness in a patient with ascites. If there is clinical concern for SBP, the ascites fluid should be sampled through a paracentesis. Laboratory analysis of the ascitic fluid should include Gram stain, culture, and cell counts. A total leukocyte count of greater than 1000/mm 3 or greater than 250 neutrophils/mm 3 is generally diagnostic of SBP since culture results are variably positive. Antibiotics with gram-negative rod coverage (e.g., third-generation cephalosporins) are considered first-line.

distractor_explanations.A: is a rare, aggressive thyroid malignancy that invades local structures such as the esophagus and trachea. It generally only occurs in older persons and carries a poor prognosis. On examination, a "hard, woody mass" may be palpable along with symptoms of dysphagia or hoarseness. Follicular carcinoma (
distractor_explanations.B: also presents with a thyroid nodule and is the second most common thyroid malignancy after papillary carcinoma. It is diagnosed on biopsy, as the neoplastic cells are noted to invade the surrounding capsule, which differentiates it from a benign follicular adenoma. It typically carries a good prognosis. Hurthle cell adenoma (
distractor_explanations.C: is a less common type of benign thyroid adenoma arising from Hurthle cells. It most commonly occurs in older females. Papillary carcinoma (
distractor_explanations.E: is the most common type of thyroid cancer and carries an excellent prognosis. It typically demonstrates empty-appearing nuclei with central clearing, nuclear grooves, and psammoma bodies on histology. Early radiation exposure in childhood is a risk factor. r " , r-- r ,

3 months ago . He has a history of major depressive disorder and alcoholism ; he has not had a drink for the past year. His medications are esomeprazole , sertraline , and vitamin B complex supplement. He has not had any
recent changes to his diet. Vital signs are within normal limits. The abdomen is flat and nontender ; bowel sounds are hyperactive and high pitched . Laboratory studies show:

Serum
Amylase activity 90 U/L

Which of the following is the most appropriate pharmacotherapy?

Administration of 100% oxygen by nonrebreather face mask
Intravenous fluid therapy and blood transfusion
Endoscopic-guided sclerosis of the esophageal varices
Placement of a transjugular intrahepatic portal shunt

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Exocrine and endocrine pancreatic insufficiency are associated with chronic pancreatitis and result from repeated episodes of acute pancreatitis leading to the destruction of acinar and islet cells. The loss of acinar and islet parenchyma can be further exacerbated if a distal pancreatectomy is performed to control symptoms or manage complications of chronic pancreatitis. The exocrine pancreas produces digestive enzymes, the absence of which leads to malnutrition (e.g., cachexia, muscle wasting), weight loss, vitamin deficiencies, and frequent, loose, foul-smelling, sometimes oily stools (steatorrhea). The diagnosis of pancreatic insufficiency is through clinical history, imaging, and biopsy. Exocrine pancreatic insufficiency is treated with oral pancreatic enzyme replacement such as pancrelipase. Endocrine pancreatic insufficiency, if present, typically results in diabetes mellitus, which requires insulin replacement therapy. Any modifiable inciting causes of pancreatitis (e.g., gallstones, alcohol use disorder, hypertriglyceridemia, hypercalcemia) should be mitigated to delay disease progression and preserve remaining native pancreatic function.

distractor_explanations.C: slows gut motility. Both are used in the management of irritable bowel syndrome. They do not play a role in the treatment of pancreatic insufficiency. Metronidazole (
distractor_explanations.D: is an antibiotic used in the management of anaerobic infections, notably C/ostridioides difficile (formerly C/ostridium difficile) and Giardia Jamblia. r " , r-- r ,

vignette.presentation:
50. While undergoing a splenectomy for immune thrombocytopenic purpura , a 49-year-old man aspirates during a difficult intubation . The diagnosis is confirmed when bile is aspirated from the trachea . Which of the following factors
is most predictive of the severity of the resulting aspiration pneumonia?

choices.text: Amount of bile present in the aspirate
Presence of solid material in the aspirate

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: The inhalation of orogastric contents is known as aspiration, and it can occur from simple fluids such as water or stomach contents such as emesis or regurgitated products. Small volume, simple fluid aspiration may be resorbed by the lung without any consequence of infection, irritation, or compromised gas exchange. In other cases, large volume aspiration may sufficiently impair gas exchange resulting in refractory hypoxia. The aspiration of acidic stomach contents may cause aspiration pneumonitis, whereas the aspiration of gastrointestinal flora and additional bacteria can cause aspiration pneumonia. The volume of aspirate is the strongest predictor of complications from aspiration, especially in the case of pneumonia, as the bacterial inoculum may overwhelm the native ability of the pulmonary alveolar defenses (macrophages, cilia, mucus) to prevent colonization, replication, and infection. Aspiration pneumonia classically presents with cough productive of foul-smelling sputum, fever, chills, chest pain, shortness of breath, and rhonchi on examination. Imaging classically shows an infiltrate in the most dependent segments of lung at the time of aspiration (e.g., in the superior segment of the inferior lobe when supine or lower lobes when erect), and treatment includes broad-spectrum antibiotics with sufficient coverage of oral flora, gram-negative rods, and anaerobes.

distractor_explanations.A: may be a factor in determining the severity of a noninfectious aspiration pneumonitis but would not play an immediate role in predicting the severity of an aspiration pneumonia. Duration of endotracheal intubation (
distractor_explanations.B: increases the risk for ventilator-associated pneumonia, which is not characteristically caused by oral flora. Typical organisms include Staphylococcus aureus and Pseudomonas aeruginosa. Presence of solid material in the aspirate (
distractor_explanations.C: increases the risk for airway obstruction and atelectasis following aspiration, and also increases the risk for pneumonia, but to a lesser extent than the overall volume of aspiration fluid. Use of prophylactic antibiotics preoperatively (
distractor_explanations.D: is indicated to prevent skin and soft-tissue infections, contamination from the operative incision, sepsis, and peritonitis in the case of intra-abdominal surgery. r " , r-- r ,

temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 72/min , and blood pressure is 110/70 mm Hg. Cardiopulmonary and abdominal examinations show no abnormalities . The right testicle is high in the right hemiscrotum , transverse , and
exquisitely tender to palpation . The left hemiscrotum is normal. Urinalysis shows no abnormalities . Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Surgical exploration of the scrotum is indicated for the management of testicular torsion. Testicular torsion occurs when the testicle twists on the spermatic cord, resulting in subsequent insufficient testicular blood supply. Patients typically present with acute, severe testicular pain, swelling, and erythema. On physical examination, the testicle typically demonstrates an abnormal lie (e.g., transverse), extreme tenderness to palpation, absent cremasteric reflex, and pain that does not improve with elevation of the scrotum (as it does in epididymitis). The diagnosis is often clinical, though in cases of uncertainty, evaluation begins with ultrasonography, which delineates testicular size, sonographic features, blood flow, and epididymal anatomy. Management requires immediate surgical exploration of the scrotum with detorsion of the spermatic cord followed by bilateral orchiopexy to prevent future testicular torsion.

distractor_explanations.B: can be used for symptomatic treatment in epididymitis and orchitis to attempt to relieve inflammation and swelling. Technetium Tc 99m sestamibi scan of the testes (
distractor_explanations.C: can be used to evaluate testicular blood flow; however, this technique is outdated as advances in technology make ultrasonography the first-line diagnostic imaging exam for the evaluation of testicular torsion. Intravenous administration of antibiotics (
distractor_explanations.D: may be necessary for severe cases of epididymitis or orchitis. These typically present as acute unilateral scrotal pain, swelling, and erythema, with decreased pain on scrotal elevation and evidence of abnormally increased vascularity on testicular Doppler ultrasonography. r , " , F'

leans forward. Three weeks ago , he underwent three-vessel coronary artery bypass grafting . His initial postoperative course was uncomplicated , and he was discharged 16 days ago . His temperature is 38.2°C (100 .8°F), pulse is
85/min and regular , and respirations are 14/min . The lungs are clear to auscultation . A friction rub is heard best over the left anterior chest. An x-ray of the chest shows no abnormalities . An ECG is unchanged from the ECG taken
on discharge . Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in diagnosis?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Echocardiography is indicated for the assessment of a pericardia! effusion in the setting of postoperative pericarditis. Pericarditis classically presents as substernal chest pain, which is often pleuritic, worsens when lying down, and improves with leaning forward. It can occur in patients with inflammatory, infectious, or malignant conditions, such as viral infection, systemic lupus erythematosus, tuberculosis, and lymphoma, and can present as a complication of myocardial infarction or cardiac surgery. On examination, pericarditis demonstrates a diastolic friction rub, described as a harsh sound heard in diastole. The condition is diagnosed clinically and supported by increased inflammatory markers such as erythrocyte sedimentation rate and C-reactive protein. If not treated, pericarditis can lead to the development of pericardia! effusions, which, if large and quickly accumulating, can result in cardiac tamponade. An echocardiography should be performed to assess for the presence of a pericardia! effusion, which may require pericardiocentesis for drainage if large. Treatment includes anti-inflammatory medications, such as indomethacin, glucocorticoids, and/or colchicine. Conditions with a similar presentation, such as acute myocardial infarction, pulmonary embolism, and aortic dissection, should also be ruled out.

distractor_explanations.D: is an invasive test performed via percutaneous catheter to assess the anatomy and patency of the coronary arteries. It is indicated for the diagnostic and therapeutic management of acute coronary syndrome (e.g .. , ST-segment elevation myocardial infarction) and for the management of chronic coronary artery disease following an abnormal stress test. explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Observation only is indicated for a nevus without suspicious features concerning for malignant melanoma. Malignant melanoma is likely to be present when a skin lesion demonstrates asymmetry, irregular-appearing borders, variable coloration, a diameter greater than 6 mm, and rapid evolution in characteristics. As well, lymph nodes are suspicious when they are greater than 1 cm, irregular, nontender, and immobile on physical examination. This patient exhibits a nonsuspicious nevus of the left cheek and a nonsuspicious posterior cervical lymph node.

distractor_explanations.D: , and needle biopsy of the nevus (

Malignant melanoma has the ability to rapidly invade and metastasize, which carries a poor prognosis when diagnosed late. r " , r-- r ,

4. A 4-year-old boy is brought to the physician because of pain and burning of his right eye after playing in a sandbox . Although he insists that something is in his eye and he continues to rub it, no foreign body is apparent. He also

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Conjunctiva! instillation of fluorescein is indicated for the evaluation of a potential corneal abrasion or residual corneal or conjunctiva! foreign body. A corneal abrasion is one of the most common eye injuries and occurs secondary to disruption of the top layer of the cornea (corneal epithelium), which can occur spontaneously or from traumatic injury from a foreign body (e.g., contact lens, sand, workplace debris). Patients typically present with eye discomfort, blurry vision, photophobia, difficulty opening the eye, and a foreign body sensation. Physical examination may demonstrate excessive lacrimation, conjunctiva! erythema, decreased visual acuity, and increased light sensitivity. Fluorescein staining is indicated to assess for a corneal injury. Fluorescein passes over intact corneal tissue but is trapped in epithelial defects, which are easily visualized under a blacklight. Treatment requires removal of any residual foreign body, copious irrigation with 0.9% saline, administration of cycloplegic eye drops, and topical antibiotics if a large abrasion is present.

For example, bitemporal hemianopia would indicate injury to the optic chiasm, most commonly related to an underlying pituitary or sellar mass (e.g., pituitary adenoma). Gram stain of conjunctiva! fluid (
